bestBHT.bht: The word 'old' in this context means someone who has been a disciple since the beginning and accompanied Jesus during His ministry. Mnason of Cyprus, an important figure in the Jerusalem Church, had likely settled in Jerusalem after preaching to the Grecians in Antioch. Assisted by other disciples, Paul was brought to Mnason to introduce him and provide accommodation. This highlights the early Christians' practice of showing hospitality to fellow believers, while also revealing that Jesus' disciples extended beyond Galilee and Judaea to other regions.

Henry Alford: The word rendered old signifies from the beginning.
He had been a disciple all through, and had accompanied our Lord during His ministry.
See ch. xi. 15, where the term is applied to the time of the Pentecostal effusion of the Spirit.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: One Mnason of Cyprus, an old disciple, c.—not an 'aged' disciple, but probably 'a disciple of old standing,'
He had come, probably, with the other Cyprians, to Antioch, 'preaching the Lord Jesus unto the Grecians,' and now he appears settled at Jerusalem.
The apostle was full of anxiety about this visit to Jerusalem, from the numerous prophetic intimations of danger awaiting him.
Albert Barnes: And brought us to Mnason of Cyprus, an old disciple."
An early convert to Christianity - perhaps one who was converted before the crucifixion of the Saviour."
The rites of hospitality were shown in a distinguished manner by the early Christians.
Marvin Vincent: Bringing with them, etc. This would imply that Mnason was at Caesarea, and accompanied Paul and his companions to Jerusalem."
It seems better to suppose that the disciples accompanied the apostle in order to introduce him to Mnason, whom they knew."
Better, as Rev., early. The rendering old might be taken to mean aged; whereas the word means of long standing.
Philip Schaff: There went with us also certain of the disciples of Cæsarea, conducting us to Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we should lodge.
Mnason was no doubt an important person in the Jerusalem Church; he is styled ‘an old or an early disciple,’ and was possibly converted during the life of our Lord Himself.
If so, it is interesting as showing that our Lord’s disciples were not limited to the natives of Galilee and Judæa.
Archibald T. Robertson: A thoroughly idiomatic Greek idiom, incorporation and attraction of the antecedent into the relative clause.
He was originally from Cyprus, but now in Caesarea.
As the number of the first disciples lessened, the next generation accorded a sort of honour to the survivors.
John Gill: old disciple; not of Aristotle, or of his sect of philosophers, or any other, but of Jesus Christ.
probably he might have seen Christ in the flesh
he is by some thought to be one of the seventy disciples
John Wesley: The disciples brought us to one Mnason, a Cyprian, an old disciple."
He was a native of Cyprus, but an inhabitant of Jerusalem.
And probably one of the first converts there.
